data:
There are three main reasons for an immediate innovation action to apply big data technologies in Healthcare. Firstly, a Healthy nation is a Wealthy nation! An improvement in health leads to economic growth through long-term gains in human and physical capital, which ultimately raises productivity and per capita GDP. Secondly, Healthcare is one of the most expensive sectors, which accounts for 10% of the EU’s GDP continuously becoming more expensive. Thirdly, as healthcare is traditionally very conservative with adopting ICT, while big healthcare data is becoming available, the expected impact of applying big data technologies in Healthcare is enormous. 
BigMedilytics will transform Europe’s Healthcare sector by using state-of-the-art Big Data technologies to achieve breakthrough productivity in the sector by reducing cost, improving patient outcomes and delivering better access to healthcare facilities simultaneously, covering the entire Healthcare Continuum – from Prevention to Diagnosis, Treatment and Home Care throughout Europe.
BigMedilytics produces: 
• A Big Data Healthcare Analytics Blueprint (defining platforms and components), which enables data integration and innovation spanning all the key players across the Healthcare Data Value Chains 
• Instantiations of the Blueprint which implement BigMedilytics concepts across 12 large-scale pilots accounting for an estimated 86% of deaths and 77% of the disease burden in Europe
• The Best “Big Data technology and Healthcare policy” Practices related to big data technologies, new business models and European and national healthcare data policies and regulations.
BigMedilytics will maximize the impact by using its Big Data Healthcare Analytics Blueprint and the Best Practices to scale-up the concepts demonstrated in the 12 pilots, to the whole Healthcare sector in Europe. It will use health records of more than 11 million patients across 8 countries and data from other sectors such as insurance and public sector.
Leadership in information and communications technology (09.04.02.01)

The project focuses on widening and deepening professional and key competences of the teachers of English and German languages. Its main aim is to improve the language abilities, development of methodology, teaching techniques and getting practical ideas to lessons, gaining knowledge of business language and language for travel and tourism.
The aim of the project is for the participants to increase general, professional and cultural level of the taught language. The other reasons for participating in the project are learning new teaching techniques and providing the pupils and students with information about the authentic language, current labour market, its requirements and demands.
The participants of the project are four teachers, two teaching German and two English language.
The teachers of German teach the language as the second or the third compulsory language at secondary and higher school, prepare the pupils and students for general leaving examination - maturita. They also prepare the students for the Final Certificate at our higher vocational school. 
The English teachers are responsible for teaching the language as the first compulsory language at secondary and higher school, prepare the pupils for general leaving examination - maturita. They also, as the German teachers, prepare the students for the Final Certificate at our higher vocational school.
The German language course is designed for eight to twelve non-native speakers teaching German at secondary schools. It consists of twenty sixty-minute lessons per week emphasising mainly teaching techniques and methodology of German language. Five extra lessons per week focus on culture, Austrian music, art, history and the cuisine, Vienna waltz and sport.
The English course is designed for minimum six non-native speakers teaching English at secondary schools. It offers twenty forty-five-minute lessons per week and it covers methodology and the language itself. Eight lessons per week will be spent on business English and English for travel and tourism.
The expected effect of the project on the participants will be improvement of their language skills, language teaching methodology development and it also will improve the quality of teaching and their professional language knowledge.
The organisation will get an opportunity to use teaching methods of higher quality and teach more effectively. That will consequently affect the teaching plans and also the School Educational Curriculum. All the above should increase the motivation of the pupils and students not only to study languages but also to become confident and succeed at finding a job at the European labour market.

Our project is studying on preventing environmental pollution and harm to human health caused by unnecessary use of plastic bags. Distribution of free plastic bags was prohibited in many European Union countries. Shopping centers and similar shops do not distribute free plastic bags in those countries. This implementation both limited consumption of plastic bags and promote people to using recyclable bags or bags made of less harmful substances. In this way, created awareness resulted in economic advantages. In addition, applied legal obligations directed people to question themselves about unrestrained usage of plastic bags. Thereby, people have changed their habits in many European Union countries. The UK is the first country to limit consumption of plastic bags, because of this our group will perform the project with an English partner and other partner groups in the UK.  Modbury Parish Council is the pioneer on this subject. We have connected with relevant partners by favor of Department for Turks Abroad and Relative Communities and Partners  and used our connections in past projects during partner search process.
The purpose of our project is to make the observation of advantages thanks to the limitation of using plastic bags and charging a fee for plastic bags in relevant country and is to provide generalization of this implementations in Turkey and other partner countries.
We have totally 7 participants in the project. According to gender equality rules, there are 4 females and 3 males. One of them is the leader of project.  One member of our group is a student of Law Faculty and have taken part in many environmental  and social projects. She works at Antalya Municipality Environmental Protection and Control Department and has analyzed the negative effects of plastic bags academically with a Tubitak project and informed our group members in the field. Another member of us is a Law Department student and is the head of Young Lawyers NGO. He carried out the coordinatorship of a project supported by Youth and Sport Ministry. The other member is a lawyer that has a Masters Degree in UK. He participated in many activities about recycling and environmental pollution.  Our team leader is a local authority., governor of Duzce Province with an advanced level of English knowledge, he graduated from international relations and he has two master’s degrees in public administration; currently he has been doing his doctorate degree. He will also greatly support our project by easing  bureaucratic process during the dissemination process. Other two group members are key members with their professionalism and ability for responsibly distribution and following, visa process, communications with partners and organization of dissemination events. All youngsters have pre-inter or intermediate level of English. We chose other partners that are interested, active, sensitive to the subject, open to collaboration, experienced and enthusiastic to the subject and between the ages of 18-30.

Activities;
To visit to England , Modbury City Council, the first country that restricts the usage and distribution of plastic bags, to monitor how this restriction became a national application from a local activity and to see how the local government support this restriction
- Interviews with local people and traders.
- With the methods of fishbone analysis and brainstorming, analyzing the situations in partner countries and preparation of effective awareness and dissemination plans,
- Designing of creative posters that will awake awareness,
- Creation of a video to create awareness,
After returning, we plan to visit and inform listed organizations and NGO to create awareness and collaborate to work together;
- Düzce Directorate of National Education,
-Düzce Directorate of Environment and Urbanization,
- Local crafts and business in Düzce,
- Düzce Directorate of Community Health,
- Düzce Chamber of Commerce and Industry,
- Antalya Directorate of National Education,
- Antalya Directorate of Environment and Urbanization,
- Local crafts and business in Antalya,
- Antalya Directorate of Community Health,
- Antalya Chamber of Commerce and Industry,
-Signature and introduction stands in two big shopping centers in Düzce and Antalya
And the partners in the project will apply similar awareness and dissemination activities in their countries. During dissemination process, local media, social media and internet sites like youtube ,Erasmus+ Project Results Platform will be used effectively.
With the project, we aim to create an awareness among youngsters, local peoples of partners, related organizations and traders and decrease the plastic bags usage rates.
The Importance of Teaching Languages through CLIL in Primary Education

Queen's Park Academy is a 4 form entry school (5 forms in Year 4) in Bournemouth with 510 pupils on roll.  In 2013, the school was inspected by OFSTED and was judged to be Outstanding in all areas.  

The school has excellent capacity for innovation and improvement and currently is involved in a variety of school to school support with other schools in the surrounding area. The school's curriculum is a creative and innovative Integrated Curriculum.  All subjects are taught through integrated projects which begin with an engaging 'hook' and culminate in an outcome which is shared with all or part of the wider school community.

As a school, we have already begun to working with international links in the form of a native Spanish teacher to educate our pupils on a two year rolling programme. We are committed to developing the quality of our curriculum, including European Languages.  In order to achieve our aims, we need to develop staff competence in both their own language skills and in teaching languages - particularly using the CLIL approach.  The Associate Principal and the Curriculum Lead at the school are key staff in implementing new language teaching approaches and other teaching staff will be able to disseminate their learning and skills to the rest of the staff an beyond  
 
We have identified  6 staff profiles:
Class Teachers, Subject Leads and Subject Specialists/, Teaching Assistants, Heads of Year, Support Staff, Associate Principal / Vice Principals

The Project is for Structured Staff Training offered by a course provider in Spain (Malaca Instituto).

Training/Activities varied according to the Development Plan and the participants' training needs,  but came from: Intensive Language Learning, Methodology of Teaching  Spanish as a Foreign Language, Language & Methodology, Language and Culture and Management Training.

The project will allow us to further the aims and objectives of our school Development Plan which has a focus on language learning.
We aim to make all staff across the school more sensitive to the importance of language learning and cultural diversity.

The competences acquired by participating staff will enable them to be more sensitive to learning problems of migrant (EAL) students  and, indeed, to native speaker students from the our catchment area which has a poor socio-economic background with consequent limited linguistic facility. We wish to develop CLIL (Content and Language Integrated Learning) in mainstream Modern Foreign Language  teaching to native and non-native English speakers

This project will increase not only teaching staff personal competences, skills and sensitivities, but given the acquired skills in teaching material development and lesson planning, will  impact on our students' foreign and native linguistic competences and on cultural sensitivity to diversity. This also generates a greater need to ensure that teachers share best practice and expertise. 

Going forward, there will be a greater enthusiasm for second language learning and for cultural exchange visits. Staff will be asked to build a range of language skills so that impact on research projects is enhanced through staff ability to disseminate results internationally and pupil transition to  secondary partners developing language learning will be more efficient. There will be an adoption of a CLIL based  approach for the growing EAL community.
